Back to 100%, thanks to https://www.yahoo.com/news/italy-pm-matteo-renzi-visit-iran-april-12-111252870.html pointed out by @ESL_Br "Rome (AFP) - Italian Prime Minister Matteo Renzi will travel to Iran next week for a two-day trip that will make him the first major leader to visit since the lifting of international sanctions against Tehran. Renzi's office said in a statement Monday that the centre-left premier would be in the Islamic Republic on April 12 and 13, without giving further details of his itinerary. Italy has led the way among Western countries in re-establishing economic ties to Iran following the lifting of international sanctions imposed over concerns the country was seeking to develop a nuclear weapons capacity. An accord to lift the sanctions was agreed last year and came into force in January. Renzi's trip follows Iranian President Hassan Rouhani's visit to Italy and France at the end of January -- a trip which resulted in a string of major trade and investment deals being signed between Tehran and the two European countries. Contracts worth an estimated 17 billion euros ($18 billion) were signed in Rome and Rouhani said he hoped that would represent only a start, as he pitched Iran as a safe base for investors looking to get into a regional market of 300 million consumers. Iran has said it wants European help to modernise and expand its rail, road and air networks as well as seeking investment to boost its manufacturing base, notably in the automobile sector. Italy was Iran's largest European trade partner before the impact of sanctions caused exchanges between the two countries to collapse.As he seeks to consolidate Italy's early lead in the race for business deals, Renzi has also unveiled plans for cultural and academic exchanges."

To make a prediction for this question, I will use the "Norms and protocols of domestic and international institutions matter" method. The relevant "international institutions" include Iran and the countries of the G7 (Canada, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, the United Kingdom, and the United States). To begin looking at Iran, it is important to consider the effects of its most recent election (http://www.vox.com/2016/3/1/11139970/iran-elections). The election results affirmed the nuclear deal, revealed a push from the Iranian people to open up more to the West, and pointed to a trend of rising moderates in Iran. These effects show a change in the norms and protocols of Iran, whose government has been traditionally been closed off to the West and viewed as "extremist." Because of these apparent changes in norms, it seems more likely than ever that Iran will host a G7 country in the coming months.  Additionally, with the U.S. at the lead, the G7 countries have made recent moves to be more open to Iran, fueled by the nuclear deal. This reveals that the norms between this international "institution" (the G7), the countries that comprise it, and the country of Iran. It would logically follow that, as trust between these entities builds, the norms between them would become more open, thus leading to a likely official state visit.  I will update this prediction as more news of the aftermath of Iran's election and the attitudes of the G7 countries is developed and revealed.

Going back down again. I can't see the Europeans doing it right now. They're bogged down with domestic issues, and don't want to irritate either the US or the Saudis. Plus they already ate their cake (lots of big deals) without it. Renzi has been mentioned as a possibility, but he is being ridiculed in the Italian press for the great statue cover-up. That has to smart. Canada isn't likely. The new Liberal government is just figuring out their policy towards Iran, and have only just removed a few items from the sanctions list. Plus, Canada is highly sensitive to the US's position, and the US is in electoral mode. Trudeau is close to the Democratic Party (one of his cabinet ministers used to be a White House speech writer etc etc), and he isn't going to want to harm them. The US isn't going to happen during an election year. Too much political fodder. Too costly. A visit by President Obama would be worth millions of votes to the Republicans. Maybe the next president, but not likely before November. Japan isn't likely until after the July deadline. Their parliament is in session, and looking at their PM's schedule, it looks like he generally sticks close to home during that period. Japan is the only one I can see as being credible though, particularly given that the South Korean PM is considering the trip. "With the deal’s finalization, Tokyo is looking to kick-start relations with Tehran and revive previous efforts at investing in Iran’s energy sector. Japan isn’t alone, of course: Russia, China and several European countries have been stepping up their efforts to get an early foothold in the Iranian market as it opens back up to the world. Japan’s motivation to compete for a share of the investment opportunities in Iran is unambiguous. As Yoshihide Suga, Japan’s chief Cabinet secretary, recently explained about the bilateral investment treaty: “The aim of these negotiations is to protect the investment activities of Japanese companies. Japan will take the necessary steps and not be later than other nations.” "One of Japan’s key targets is Iran’s potentially lucrative Azadegan oil fields, near the border with Iraq.  . . . . Japan, after all, remains highly dependent on foreign sources of energy, especially from the Middle East; last year, more the 80 percent of Japan’s crude oil imports came from the region. The largest suppliers are countries from the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC), such as Saudi Arabia (34 percent), the United Arab Emirates (24 percent), Qatar (11 percent) and Kuwait (7 percent). Iran’s market share of oil exports to Japan has dropped precipitously over the past decade, from a peak of 16 percent of Japan’s total oil imports in 2003 to 5 percent last year.
" . . . Tokyo’s energy needs have been magnified by the four-year self-imposed moratorium on nuclear reactors as a result of the 2011 nuclear crisis at Fukushima. Only recently have a few reactors gone back online in the country. Japan previously relied on nuclear power generation for nearly a third of its domestic energy. " . .  .Abe has made three trips to the Middle East since he was elected in December 2012. His extensive itineraries included visits to Turkey (twice), Egypt, Israel, Palestine, Jordan, Kuwait, the UAE, Oman, Qatar, Saudi Arabia and Bahrain. With the Iran deal and potentially improved ties between Tehran and the international community, it is possible that Abe may look to visit Iran in the coming years. At the very least, one can expect a higher exchange of senior diplomats and business people between the two countries. Just last month, Japan’s vice minister for economy, trade and industry visited Tehran, accompanied by several business officials in the oil and gas sector. "Yet despite these positive trends, Japan will likely take a cautious route in its reset with Iran, even if the mutual investment deal is reached and Japanese businesses return to Iran. Tokyo remains sensitive to the lingering problems in the relationship between its key ally, the U.S., and Iran, which are not limited to the nuclear issue. During a meeting with Iran’s foreign minister earlier this year, Japan’s foreign minister, Fumio Kishida, expressed concern about longstanding military ties between Iran and North Korea and requested that Iran sever “all military cooperation with North Korea.” Japan is also opposed to any destabilizing activities that Iran is undertaking in Yemen and Syria. And on the nuclear issue, Japan, as a strong opponent of nuclear proliferation, must continue to insist that Iran remain transparent and in compliance with the nuclear agreement. Investment might be a carrot for compliance, but it won’t overshadow deeper political sensitivities that will continue to keep Japan-Iran ties modest in the short term.

While I see the probability of a visit within the timeline as low in general, I'm going to break with my colleagues here and suggest that the US is, in fact, the most likely visitor. This is precisely the sort of "Nixon in China" moment to serve as a capstone to Obama's foreign policy legacy, and there have been rumors since 2013 (and more serious ones recently) that suggest he's floated the idea.  However, the nuclear deal must actually be ratified and have time to go into effect before such a trip is possible, and with the remaining time an invitation must be formally extended and accepted, which is by no means a fast process. On the other *other* hand, July is probably the latest that Obama could make such a trip without interfering in the November elections, so this could be incentive to speed up a bit. Too soon. A visit is not likely, in my opinion, until most of the U.N. sanctions are removed and there is at least a partial lifting of the European and U.S. sanctions. U.N. sanctions relief won't come until the spring, at the earliest, according to the UK Foreign Minister. Any G7 leader's visit will likely be a big event and won't be rushed. Moreover, there will be plenty of advance warning once a visit is scheduled. Meanwhile, there are plenty of other ways to boost relations with an "opened" Iran, including visits by cabinet-level ministers, etc. There is also diplomatic protocol which can use up time. My guess is that an invitation will be extended first and the response will come some time later. For example, PM Matteo Renzi extended an invitation to President Rouhani to come to Rome, and he has yet to respond. Finally, each of the G7 leaders has to consider domestic politics. There is a reason why, among Western European nations, only the Austrian presidents (Fischer this year, Klestil in 2004, Waldheim in 1991) have visited Iran since the Revolution. I have to fact-check this last point, though.
